Justification: To assess for signs of infection, such as elevated white blood cell count, which may indicate a bacterial infection.
To evaluate for inflammation in the body, which can help differentiate between viral and bacterial infections.
To identify any viral pathogens that may be causing the upper respiratory symptoms and fever.
To rule out urinary tract infection, which can also present with fever in infants.
To check for signs of ear infection, such as fluid in the middle ear or redness of the eardrum.
